document.text: Young Law Tinkers. The Richmond Dispatch of last Sunday publishes brief sketches of four of Virginias young Lawmakers, viz. Senators Eugeue Withers and H. D. Elood, Hon. John Wood Fish- burne, and Joseph E. Willard, mak ing special mention of the two young Senators as having been the most active workers in this session of the legislature. Speaking of- the Senator from Appomattox, the Dispatch says Mr. Flood, who represents the Appomattox District in the Senate, was 30 years old on the 2d of last September, and is next to the youn gest member of the body. He has been a member of the General As sembly since he was 22 years old. He is chairman of the committee on Fish and Game of the Senate, second on Privileges and Elections, fourth on Courts of Justice, and is a mem berof the Committee on Printing. He is a close attendant upon the ses sions of his committees and a good worker. He was the leader in the Senate of those who favored our present election laws, without radi cal changes, and made one of the ablest speeches on this, subject that has been made in the Senate. In his defence of our election laws he was supported by many of the stron gest senators. He isbold and aggressive in what ever he advocates, and rarely fails in his undertakings. He represents a section in which party feeling is higher than in any other sectiou of the State, and the last contest in his district was very bitter but the re suit was a splendid triumph for Mr. Flood. He carried the district by I, 000. which was lost by the Demo crats in 1894. He has a large and extensive law practice, which he never neglects for anything except to perform his political duties. He is considered particularly strong as a jury lawyer. As Attorney for the Commonwealth for his county he has been particularly successful, rarely ever failing to secure a convic tion when he asks for it. Mr. Flood is spoken of as a for - midable candidate for Congress in the coming fight. If he is nomi nated, it is certain that the eastern part of the district, which is the doubtful end, will give the Demo cratic ticket a splendid majority. He redeemed his county from re publicanism in 1887, when he was

document.text: You will do well to call on Morris Bros.A Co.,of Farmville,and examine their stock of Buggies, Jumpers, and Wagons, which, for the next 30 dayy, - - they are offering at remarkably low prices. The noted Silver King, the best buggy on the market, and worth - 75, thev will sell for 60. Their  jumpers range from 16 to 25. We call your especial attention to their Farmers Favorite Drill, of which and, every farmer should have one. d T he T imes E ditor .The quali fication of Hon. H. D. Flood as a ps representative has impressed theosts. people of his community, and it is pertinent that the attention of the electors of the tenth Congressional? District should he called to his em inent fitness for Congress. Reared in a home of culture and refinement, educated in the best schools of the I State,experienced in legislative work, he is fully qualified for the position. The distinction he has attained was not won through the influence of relatives of wide political reputation, but by his own individual worth, and because his constituents recog nized in him a man of broad sympa thy,superior talents, and the power j to make those talents trusted. While a member of the lower and the upper branch of the Legislature, he made every endeavor to win the approbation of his constituents, and I their endorsement of him for I Congress testifiied that his work was not in vain. His name is intimately I associated with the important laws enacted when he was a member of the Senate, and while there, he proved himself a keen discerner of the intrigues of his antagonists. Not a stain of treachery rests on his political record. The energy,force and persistence of Mr. Flood are remarkable, and insure him success in every undertaking. He knows the true needs of the District, and will not sacrifice the interest of the county to his personal I considerations. His probity, com bined with his knowledge of theworld I places him above the tricks and I bribes of trusts and rings. His intellectual and executive ability, supported by a character above j reproach gives him preeminence as a candidate for Cougress. A Desinterested Friend. document.text: You are cordially invited to the regular preaching service, at Zion Baptist Church Sunday, May 4 at 11. a.m. The Male Chofus is having its second anniversary Sun day, May 4 at 3 p.m. at Zion Baptist. The. Senior- Usher Board met Sunday at 11 a.m. with vice president Barbara Hunter calling the meeting to order. Our chaplain, Mr. Waverly Gray was in charge of the devotion. Mrs. Nannie Johnson, recording secre tary, took minutes. The Usher Board is planning for their anniver sary the second Sunday .in June. You are cordially invited to our Mothers Dfcy program on the second Sunday in May at 11 a.m. Our guest speaker will be the. Rev. H. O. Flood, and the Male Chorus will perform. It is sponsored by the Ladies Aid. Mrs. G. Ws Wiggins will be the M.C. The deaconess second anni- verary was a success at the Zion Baptist Church Sunday. Rev. Charles Lewis and the choir from Amherst were the guetoia Our sympathy goes out to the Snell and Williams family in the loss of their joved one, Mr. Aubrey Snell. We are praying for Our Sick everywhere. . Mrs. Romaine Lipscomb, Mrs. Pinky Davis, Mrs. Maude Lipscomb, Rev. Rob ert Jones and his mother, Mrs. Mary Belle Miller, all of Cumberland County and, also. Rev. Samuel Terry and Rev. Charles Rice of Lynchburg, all visited Mrs. Magnolia Franklin ip her home recently. I Misses Sybil and Cindy Franklin recently spent a few. days in Bluefield, W. Va., with their relatives and friends.

Harrisonburg.In the little hamlet ef Royal Run, Shenandoah county, a mother and her daughter were the brides in a double wedding. Miss B. Annie Smoots was wedded to John M. Pence, of Forestville, while her  mother, Mrs. Sarah C. Smoots, and j Thomas J. Estep, of Cootes Store,  Rockingham county, were married. The ceremony was performed at the j home of the brides mother and grand parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ananias Polk, j Rev, A. K. Beck was the officiating minister. Charlottesville.  The usual fall j meeting of the board of visitors of the University of Virginia was attended by the rector, Armistead C. Gordon, j of Staunton Daniel Harmon, of j Charlottesville W. H. White, of Rich- j mend W. Drewery, of Petersburg J. j K. M. Norton, of Alexandria George I 6. Shackelford, of Orange H. D. j Flood, of Appomattox, and John W. 1 Craddock, of Lynchburg. The visitors accepted the gift by the Peabody Ed- j ucation Board of 40,000 for the erec- j tion of a suitable building for a home j for the department of education. The gift was made on condition that the I university undertake to maintain such j a department at an expenditure of not less than 10,000 a year. President j Alderman and the medical faculty were empowered to make such regu- j latlons as may seem wise on account j of the rapid increase of the first-year i medical class and overtaxed facilities I of the medical laboratory. Five sc hoi- I arshlps carrying exemption from tui-  tion and one-half of the fees In the j academic department were awarded to f the live white high schools In the DSs- j triet of Columbia. Charles G. Maphis, of Charlottesville, was elected profes- sor of secondary education to sue-  ceed Prof. Bruce R. Payne. Petersburg.The quickest criminal trial on record In this State occurred in the Corporation Court, of Peters burg, Friday. Four youthful highway men, ranging in age from 14 to 18 years, Charles C. Williams and James Davis, of Fort Worth, Tex., and Joseph L. Cary and J. L, Brown, of Denver, Col., held up and robbed, at the point of their pistols, Charles C. Brown, ol this city, getting his gold watch arid chain and 80 in money. This occur red Wednesday night. The youths were arrested In Weldon Thursday morning and brought hack at night. Friday morning they pleaded guilty In the police court. At noon they were indicted by the grand Jury, They pleaded guilty, on arraignment, elect ed to be tried by the court, and, In less than an hour had been sentenced, each to 12 years in the penitentiary. The boys bad lived in New York city for two years and left that city for a tour of the South a week ago. They were armed with six pistols and In their possession were found many watches, stickpins and Jewelry, the fruits of heir various robberies. A watch arid a stickpin belonging to Samuel T. Taylor, of Baltimore, who was held up and robbed in that city Sunday night, were recovered. A watch and chain belonging to A. W. Harmon, of Richmond, who was rob bed on Tuesday, were also recovered. Suffolk, Benjamin L. Roberts re signed as treasurer of Isle of Wight county and W. Elliott Lai tie was ap pointed In his stead by Judge iJ. I. White, of the Circuit Court. Mr. Rob erts has filled lhe office for many years and was renominated on the Demo cratic ticket at tlic Hpring primaries, but fulled to have his name on the ticket at, the November election. Lai no entered a throe-corned Democratic fight and won the election this month. Ills regular ti me would not ordinarily begin until next year. Lain qualified today.

document.text: Work is progressing on a proj ect to build two two-lane bridges at Bent Creek, one over the James River and the other over the CO Railroad tracks, and to straighten out the approahes on both sides of the bridges. The E. P. Blankenship Co. of Salem is contractor for the Job which will cost approximately 920,000, according to Harry L. Caiden, project superintendent for the firm. Francis E. Tyler, who mov ed to Appomattox in 1963 after buying. Eldon,, the home of the late Hal 0 . Flood, is inspector on this project for the state highway department. The bridge over the river will be 647 feet long, with a 28-foot wide roadbed, and will be ap proximately 33 feet above nor mal water level. The bridge over the railroad tracks will be 608 feet long with a 28-foot roadbed, and will have 45 feet 8 inches clearance over I the tracks. Both will be steel girder type  bridges. Each bridge will have two abutments and five piers.

document.text: Womans Club Lists Opening Fall Meeting o The first meeting of the Appo mattox Womans Club for the 1955- 1956 season will be held Monday, September 12 at 300 p. m. in the Appomattox High School Cafeteria. Hostesses for the meeting will be Mrs. G. F. Abbitt, Jr., Mrs. H. C. Pulliam, Mrs. J. D. McDeamon and Mrs. H. Y. Spencer. The program for the meeting is designed to acquaint both new mem bers and old with the scope of Womans Club work. The chairmen of the departments will discuss the work of their departments. These include Mrs. F. F. Carr, Chairmen of the American Home Department Mrs. H. A. Gurney, Chairman of Educa tion and International Affairs Mrs. J. R. Lawson, Chairman of Public Affairs and Legislation Mrs. Mil dred Alvis, Chairman of the Welfare Department and Mrs. Roger Nor fleet, Chairman of Fine Arts.  Mrs. Joel W. Flood, Vice-president of the Alice Kyle District of the Vir ginia Federation of Womans Clubs, will discuss the work of Womans Clubs on a district and state level and Mrs. Charles F. P. Crawley will talk about the General Federation of Womans Clubs, which has a total membership of eleven million women. A coffee hour at 300 oclock will precede the business meeting which starts at 330.

document.text: witness said Beatty suggested croton oil, and I said no, that waa dangerous, and Dempsey said he knew a powder which would be better. Dempsey said he had used these powders to Chicago and he had broken a strike to four days. It is not dangerous. Dempsey said be would guarantee us fifty dollars each and our expens. Wegot no powders that day. We then left tbe hall together and talked about it. Beatty said we were to get fifty dollars each, and we were to get a gold watch and chain if we went. David son sid that of tbe fifty dollars promised him he got bat fourteen dollars. Attorney Brennen subjected the .witness to a severe cross eassitStioa, hut did not materially weaken Us evidence. Davidron, however, admitted that he was arrested late in November and taken into the St.- Nicholas building and waa sworn, and told the story he had just told. Then he was released. Gallagher was arrested before that. He said they had it down to black and white, and he had to tell all he knew. Mr. BrennenAre you to get a diamond watch for this? Oh, yes I guess so like the one I got from Dempsey. Captain BeckYqu were promised noth ing for coming here, were you? No, sir. J. H. Ford, a detective, swore I know Beatty, Gallagher and Davidson. On Dec. 1 1 heard a conversation between Beatty, Gallagher and Davidson, to which Beatty told abont the powders and .what they con tained. Gallagher said he believed if Dempsey was home the strike would be won, but Beatty said he thought not. I heard Gallager say Tom Brady first sug gested croton oil. On Dec. 4 1 overheard a talk between Gallagher and Beatty, which was about the same as the former one. Beatty said Turkish rhubarb end snuff was in tha powders and it was not necessary to tell the rest. Gallagher said he could take the powders and go west add break np some strike there, and told Beatty to go to Homestead next day and get the receipt if he had to pay five dollars, as there was money to it for both of them.  Louis Welters, steward of the restaurant to tbe Homestead mill, testified that he noticed unaccountable sickness soon after employing Gallagher as a cook. He said that to spite of the best of food he and his wife become very ill, and bad never fully recovered. He had several times seen  Beatty talking to Gallagher to tbe mill. Beatty was held in 5,000 bail for trial at court. - _____ _ A Flood Test Sait. P ittsburg , Dec. 19.Suit has been en tered to the United States circuit court agtenstthe South Fork Fishing club by Jffiies Jenktos and wife, of Youngstown, O in the right of Mrs. Jenkins for 20,000 damages for injuries received to the Johns town flood. This is the first suit ever en tered directly against the South Fork club for its connection with the flood, and is re garded as a test suit.

document.text: with two good looking boys came in the coach and took a seat just be hind the one I was iu, and a friend who was on the same errand as I took a seat just iu front. He and I talked for some time and my curio sity was to know the woman just behind me, and I turned to get better look and to my surprise found a negro woman, who lived within five miles of my home. She and her boys looked so genteel and be haved so nicely the conductor no donbt said, All coons look a like to me. Talking about my city cou sin, walking down the street in one of the principal ones with a dear little fellow five years old- holding my hand, he looked up and said, Uncle V you look like a country hay-seed. By chance I looked in to the mirror and thought the little fellow wasnt far wrong and I never loved him less for commenting on my looks. Eddie Anderson commenced to plant corn a few days ago with a new corn planter, a 13.50 one painted up pretty red, yesterday he left his horse to go a few steps for a bag of guano, and the horse looked back and saw the sun shin- iug on t le red planter and gave one spring and away he went over a five foot fence with planter high in the air, and 30on out of sight down a cart road and through a piece of woods for half a mile, and by some means got unhooked, and ran a few hundred yards farther and stopped. Strange to say but little damage was done to horse or planter. An other piece of advice. Boys dont leave yonr horse hitched. Mr. Henry Chappell closed up James River District assessment yesterday, Joel Elcan finished this, Francisco, district some time ago. Eddie McCraw is home for a few days. He will leave again next week. Miss Lucy McCraw is home after spending the winter in Florida. Mrs. Annie Anderson is on a visit to Crew. Mrs. Mamie and Nannie Ander son are visiting Mrs. W- K. Saund ers today. Mrs. Alice Flood started to see her children in Richmond to-day. Tabernacle meeting, August 18th to 28th. Everybody come. Miss Ellen Steger is still under the care of Dr. Nowlin. Glad to say she is improving. Charley Wingo, the mail carrier from this office to Evergreen, who was thrown from his horse at Ever green last Saturday, is still suffering very much. Dr. Morris replaced his Bhoulder and found several other bones broken. Trouble dont come single hand ed. Monday came orders from the department for his suspension as carrier. A petition is now being circulated for h8 reinstatemsnt as carrier. It is believed be gives en tire satisfaction to a large majority of the patrons on the route. He is a cripple, a poor, but honest man. He has the sympathy of many. Route 1 from this office-has been ordered extended, beginning May 16, from Cattersons Corner up the Pickshin to Peter Goius road, re tracing thence along old route. Sorry to say Mr. T. H. Bryants wife is still sick and has been under the care of the doctor several mouths.

document.text: With TWENTY-THREE volunteer clerks assisting through long hours out of pure patriotism, and with two paid clerks putting in many hours of free overtime, the Appo mattox County War Price and Ra tion Board is waging an uphill bat tle to administer the rapidly ex panding activities of the Office ol Price Administration. The Ration Board itself has been in s ssion every day this week from 1 to 6 P. M. and will continue its five-hour daily meetings through July 22, at least, in an effort to act on truck and non-highway appli cations for gasoline under the new rigid gas rationing which goes into effect July 22. The board members, who are giving their services with out pay, urge that wherever at all possible, passenger cars owners give their  A books a thorough trial before they appeal for a supple mental ration. Bolunteer clerks who are helping applicants fill out the complicated blanks for service rations of gas, are Mrs. Joel W. Flood, chairman, Mrs. Gordon 9pencer, Mrs. J, T. Hunter, Mrs. J. C. Caldwell, Mrs. Caroline B. Cates, Mrs. J. T. Hunt er, Misses Myrtle Smith, Virginia Christian and Mildred McDearmon, and W. E. Hancock and S. A. Law- son.

document.text: With the Vice President Dr. Merwyn Williamson presiding in the absence of the President, Mr. Gilbert Lusk, the Appomat tox County Historical Society held its regular October meeting recently. The resignation of the President, due to a transfer of professional duties to Gettys burg National Park was accepted with regrets. Highlight of the October meeting focused on a seven hundred dollar donatimi for historical research from the Woodmen of the W orld, donation of 1914 news articles and other documents concern ing the late Congressman Henry D. Flood, and the Birth Pangs of Appomattox County depicted in a talk by Mr. Ron Wilson. Mrs. Harry Clark Rucker presented the Flood news articles to the Glory of God and to the members of the society. To her the beauty of any possession is dependent on  the degree to which it is shared i with others. Amy possession to predoifl to share is not worth  having. The thing then becomes j the master of the man. Mrs. Rucker, the former j Helen Nowlin, the great-grand-1 daughter of Lawyer John Woodson whose office is one of ! the restored buildings at J Appomattox National Park, is i the daughter of the late Annie ! Thornhill and Albert Sidney ! Nowlin. Her mother, from the I Hollywood area of the county, and her father, from the! Oakville area, are widely j related throughout the county. The firuest speaker for the evening, Ron Wilson, Historian at Appomattox Court House Rational Historic Park, spoke on th e Birth Pangs of Appomattox County,1845 - 1870. The speech, based on research, one by Dr.  John Moore, Research H istorian, University of Virginia, depicted the February 8,1845 birthing of Appomattox County from the parent counties of Buckingham, Campbell, Prince Edward and

The club has accepted this invitation, and Mrs. R. C . Hubbard, Mrs. K . C. Gre gory and Mrs. F . F . Carr will make the arrangement. M. The club decided to plant a dog wood tree at the Surrender Grounds in memory of Mrs. Bessie V . Cald well and mark it as such. This dog wood planting along the Hal Flood Highway has been chosen as a mem orial project of the club. Mrs. L. Crawley was appointed as chairman of a resolution committee in mem ory of Mrs. Caldwell, a past presi dent of the club and an active mem ber for many years. This years yearbook is also dedicated to her memory. Three Peace Roses will be award ed at the close of the club year. One will be for the exhibitor who wins the most points in horticulture by bringing horticulture specimens to and receiving awards at monthly meetings one to the amateur ar ranger who wins the most points by receiving ribbons at monthly meet ings, and a third to the novice ar ranger one who has not won a blue ribbon in a flower show or three rib bons at monthly meetings who re ceives the most points at monthly meetings. document.text: with the power of selecting and ap pointing the members of the various committees, which committees un der those rules, passed on all pro posed legislation, framed the langu age of the bills, and practicall de cided whether or not legislation should be enacted by the House Under the present rule, the mem bers of the various committees are elected by a majority vote of tbe memberrs of the House. AJao, under tbe Cannon rnles, tbe Speaker was chairman of the power ful committee on rules, and since he bad the appointment of his brother members on that committee, he ac tually controlled the shaping aDd direction of all legislation brought before the House. Under the pre sent rales, not only is the Speaker shorn of bis former autocratic power to appoint members of com mittees, and thns to control the ac tion of the committees, bnt he him self is not permitted to be a member of the committee on roles. Not content with the above-men tioned changes, the House progres sives adopted certain rnles which changed the committees from arbi trary bodies to advisory bodies, and which greatly enlarged the power and influence of the individual members of the Honse. For in stance, under the Cannon rnles, the chairman of a committee could practically prevt a vote being taken on a measure which had been referred to bis committee while un der the prednt rules, although a committee cnairman is influential and powerful when it comes to shaping legislation coming before his committi e, he cannot prevent thy Honse from voting as to whet her or not a measure shall pass the House. The standpat Republicans, toget her with a few reactionary Demo crata, most of whom have since been retired to the shades of private life, fought hard againss the revision of the Cannon rnle, bnt tbey were overwhelmingly defeated, the new rnles were adopted, and Cannon- ism took its place among the things that used to be. In the fighting that preceded tbe final victories of the progressives in the lower Honse of Congress, Mr. Flood was always on the firing line, and he, together with Bepresenta tives A. Mitchell Palmer of Penn sylvania, Clande Kitchin of North Carolina, and James Hay of Vir ginia, ably assisted Bepresentative Oscar W. Underwood of Alabama in the bringing about of those pro gressive reforms that practically re stored to the people the power to shape legislation in the halls of Congress. Previously, when tbe Bepnbli- cans were in control of the Honse, Mr. Flood had frequently attacked the reactionaries who had entrench ed themselves behind the Gannon rnles, and on one occasion when the infamy of those rnles was under discussion on the floor of the Honse, particularly with reference to their application to a bill for the relief of the tobacco growers of Virginia, the member from the Tenth Dist rict, himself the author of a mea sure having for its purpose the re- ief of the Virginia growers, rose in his seat, and by the grace of Mr. Speaker Cannon, delivered a most forctble address in which he scored the antocratic power exercised by the Cannon regime, which, be re marked, had taken from the mem bers of the HonBe the powers dele gated to them by the Federal Con stitntion. Space does not permit me to give yon more than a taste of the milit ant progressivism with which that particular speech was charged, so 1 must content myself with quoting one small paragraph, reserving for my next weeks letter a fuller ac count of the speech, whioh itself alone stamps Henry D. Flood as one of that band of active progres sives whose efforts jrill be a step nearer fnll fruition when Woodrow Wil.on takes his sent in the White Honse. Mr. Flood said When Oliver Cromwell cleared ont liie Parliinent Honse with a file of soldier, it whb no whit more tyranmoal, no whit moie subversive sf the fundamental principles of representative government, than this aeeumptiou of a power which should only be exercised by a ma jority of -this Honse,namely tbe power to legislate. The above words are a matter of record. Tbey stamp the man who uttered them as the kind of fight ing progressive who counts. O b s e r v e r .

document.text: With the fourteen counties growing dark-fired tobacco represented at Farmville last Saturday, a total of 68 of the acreage was reported signed with the proposed Dark-Fired Growers Association. Since it has been declared that no organization would be attempted without a 75 sign-up, the drive to secure signed contracts was extended to June 25, when the final meeting will be held. A num ber of speakers addressed the farmers and their representives present, and it was universally agreed that unless a 75 sign up could be obtained by June 25, all the plans would be abandoned. Speaking of the meeting in Farmville Saturday, J. W. Flood, who attended, said, The balance of power is now in the hands of the non-signer. It is up to them whether or not we have an association. C. T. Moses, campaign chairman for Appomattox, declared that the move for contracts would be pushed with vigor in an effort to put over the necessary 75 Both Appomattox a n d Buckingham county were among the leaders in acreage signed up with the association. Appomattox had over 2,6000 acres signed, and about 800 contracts, said to be an 80 coverage. ----------o ------------

document.text: With electric service restor ed to nearly all customers,Vir ginia Electric and Power Com pany crews continued t h e i r round-the clock efforts to clean up and repair power facilities, and to determine the extent of damage caused by the flood. T. Justin Moore, Jr., Vepco president, said, It is impos sible at this time to estimate damage completely until all the mud, water and debris have been removed from the power stat- sions, substations, and trans mission and distribution lines that were in the path of the food. Current estimates of dam age, he said, Amount to 3.5 million and may exceed that, depending upon conditions at the Bremo Power Station. Despite a huge dike that protected the station during the C a m i l l e storm in 1969, the Bremo stat ion was inundated to a level of six feet above the turbine and boiler room operating floors. Damage to the system would have been far greater, Mr. Moore said, except for the strenuous efforts of Vepco per sonnel, many of whom worked from Wednesday through the week end with only a few hcthrs, rest, first in trying to prevent complete disruption and then in cleaning up and restoring serv ice. It is impossible to express just how proud we are of the work these men and women have done. All of us also owe tremen dous thanks to the men and wom en in municipal, county and state government services, the volunteer rescue squads, Nat ional Guard, Coast Guard, po lice and fire departments and to many others who joined forc es to aid the unfortunate, keep order and reduce the havoc of

document.text: With deepest sorrow the Womans Club of Appomattox pays tribute to the memory of one of its Organ izing and Charter Members, Bessie V. Harwood Caldwell, whose death occured on June 24th, 1955 . Public spirited to a high degree she was an unfailing worker in all good causes. Over the years every progressive movement in Church and community has owed much to her support, for Bessie V. was a leader in educational, health, recreational, and civic activities. From early youth she was a faithful and devot ed member of Liberty Baptist Church, and was a pillar of strength in its organizations and Church life. We pay tribute to her life of in spiration and accomplishments. She was devoted to her children, family, and home always loyal to her friends true to her convictions strong in her Christian faith, and optimistic in her outlook. Even unto the end her thoughts and plans were in consideration of others. In spite of her progressing ill. ness she kept up with her usual in terests with a courageous spirit. In no greater way did she exemplify her bravery than in her efforts to seek and use every known means of medical treatment, not solely for the purpose of her own recovery but also that others similiarly strick en might be helped. Though she is gone, always in our midst is she because Love makes memory eternal. Mrs. Robert C. Hubbard Mrs. Joel W. Flood Mrs. Jerry A. Burke, Chairman Resolution Committee. October 3, 1955. ltc

document.text: With an attendance of forty mem bers and guests indicated, the Appo mattox Lions Club will o u if w t Baseball Night event tonight at 8.30 at its regular semi-monthly meeting. Honored guests will be fifteen mem bers of the Lee Theatre ball team, Appomattox entry in the Skyline League. The Appomattox team is leading the league by one full game, .with only.two more games to play. Isadore Oppleman, of Lynchburg, president of the Skyline League, will also be a guest of the Lions tonight. A feature of the program will be the announcement of the winner of toe balloting for MJost Valuable Player on the Appomattox tealra. A ballot box has been displayed in the drug store all the week and the baseball fans have been casting their ballots for the player they consider to be of most value to the team. The ballot box will be opened this afternoon at five oclock and the re sults will be announced at tonights dinner by Judge Joel W. Flood. A purse has been made up by the Lions to be presented to the .winner. Individual members of the  team will be presented by Lion John C. Caldwell, but Lion president Calvin Robinson promises the players that they wont have to make a speech.
